question.text: What does actually mean here?
question.input_text: ‘We’re meeting him at the office.’ ‘<item>Actually</item>, we’re meeting him at his hotel.’
option: In fact, we’re not meeting him at the office but at his hotel.
We’re meeting him at his hotel now and at his office later.
question.answer: In fact, we’re not meeting him at the office but at his hotel.

exercise.rubric: Are these sentences right: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.text: I’m <item>quite fitter</item> since I started jogging.
I’m <item>completely fitter</item> since I started jogging.
Don’t start work until you’re <item>quite better</item>.
Don’t start work until you’re <item>completely better</item>.

exercise.rubric: Better, rather or both?
Look at this sentence. What does it mean?

question.text: #singletouch
option: We can’t tell from this sentence alone.
answer: We can’t tell from this sentence alone.

exercise.rubric: Right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: The crowd was too big for the police to <item>control</item>.
The police were <item>controlling</item> everyone’s papers.
I found the car difficult to <item>control</item> at high speeds.
I took the car to the garage and asked them to <item>control</item> the steering.

exercise.rubric: Right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: My parents live in <item>a nice country</item> near Oxford.
Would you rather live in <item>a town</item> or <item>a country</item>?
Which <item>countries</item> have you worked in?

exercise.rubric: Right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: She looks good in <item>a red dress</item>.
He looks good in <item>an evening dress</item>.

exercise.rubric: Choose the right option for each sentence.

#singletouch and come downstairs at once!

question.text: ‘Did you enjoy the party?’ ‘Yes, I <item>enjoyed</item> very much.’

feedback.desc: <should_be>’Did you enjoy the party?’ ’Yes, I enjoyed it very much.’</should_be>

question.text: I don’t <item>enjoy to look after</item> small children.

feedback.desc: <should_be>I don’t enjoy looking after small children.</should_be>

question.text: ‘We’re going to Paris for the weekend.’ ‘<item>Enjoy yourselves</item>!’

text: I become a millionaire, I’ll still be a socialist.
I didn’t know anybody at the party, I had a nice time.

question.text: Look at this sentence. What does it mean?
question.input_text: He left her ten years ago, but <item>even now</item> she still loves him.
option: She still loves him just as much as before.
In spite of everything that has happened, she still loves him.
question.answer: In spite of everything that has happened, she still loves him.

question.text: Which is the right beginning for this sentence: A or B?
option: It’ll take a long time and I’ll need to save my money, but ...
I don’t know what I’m going to do next year; ...
question.answer: It’ll take a long time and I’ll need to save my money, but ...

exercise.rubric: Are these sentences right: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.text: I explained her my problem.
I explained my problem to her.
Can you suggest us a restaurant?
Can you suggest a restaurant to us?

exercise.rubric: Right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: Her uncle <item>suggested her to get</item> a job in a bank.
Her uncle <item>suggested that she should get</item> a job in a bank.
Her uncle <item>suggested getting</item> a job in a bank.

exercise.rubric: Right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: I’m <item>getting</item> tired – let’s go home.
Wayne’s <item>getting</item> a lovely kid.

feedback.desc: <should_be>Wayne’s getting to be a lovely kid.</should_be>

exercise.rubric: Rewrite these sentences by replacing the highlighted verb with an equivalent, beginning with get.

sample.text: You can’t <item>make</item> him <item>leave</item> his bed in the morning.
answer: You can't get him out of bed in the morning.

question.text: <item>Make</item> the dog <item>leave</item> the bedroom.

right: Get the dog out of the bedroom.

question.text: <item>Remove</item> your papers from my desk.

right: Get your papers off my desk.

question.text: Will this bus <item>return</item> us to the airport?

right: Will this bus get us back to the airport?

I’m going <item>to home</item>.

Anna enjoys <item>city life</item>.

Are the banks <item>open</item> today?

right: Could you turn on the radio? I want to hear the news.

question.text: Who left the taps <item>open</item>?

right: Who left the taps turned on?

You’ve had <item>my same idea</item>.

Her hair’s the same colour <item>like</item> her mother’s.

I behave kindly towards the strikers.
question.answer: I agree with the strikers’ aims.

text: I’m going to do my exams, and

question.text: After the theatre we had supper and went to a nightclub; then after all we went home.

feedback.desc: After all is wrong in this sentence. Finally, at last, in the end or after that should be used instead. 361

question.input_text: I asked Jack to go home.
option: I wanted Jack to go home.
I asked Jack if I could go home.
It can mean either A or B.
question.answer: I wanted Jack to go home.

question.text: What does the reply mean?
question.input_text: ‘Did you enjoy the play?’ ‘I’m afraid I didn’t like it <item>at all</item>.’
option: I didn’t like all of it.
I didn’t like any of it.
question.answer: I didn’t like any of it.

question.text: Which question(s) can this answer: A, B or both?

text: to hear from the bank about our loan.

‘Hello, Jack. Nice to see you.’ ‘<item>Actually</item>, my name’s Andy.’

question.text: <item>The reason that</item> I came here was to be with my family.
<item>The reason why</item> I came here was to be with my family.
<item>The reason</item> I came here was to be with my family.
<item>The reason why</item> I came here was <item>because</item> I wanted to be with my family.

feedback.desc: It’s a common structure, but some people consider it wrong.

question.text: <item>The reason why</item> I came here was <item>that</item> I wanted to be with my family.
